Margaret is now applying for a loan of GHS 300 to purchase the improved stove to protect her family from indoor air pollution. Margaret is thankful for her micro lenders for their generous support in saving her family from health hazards and helping to protect the forest.

loans.use: To buy a clean cook stove

loans.name: Emoa Ku Group

texts.en: Felicia is a 40-year-old married woman with five children. She lives with her family in Assin Wawase in the Central Region of Ghana. All of her children are currently attending school. Felicia is a peasant farmer who grows cassava, plantain and maize to help her husband feed their family. Felicia also processes palm oil, which she sells in the local market during market days. Felicia has been doing this for the past 15 years. She belongs to Emoa Ku Group. Felicia's main problem is obtaining funds to purchase an Elsa clean cook stove. She spends 5 GHS daily to buy firewood, which is now difficult to get. The Elsa clean-cook stove uses waste products, such as palm Kernel shells, as fuel, which is found everywhere in her community. Palm kernel shells are a by-product of her oil processing.  Felicia will save 5 GHS daily from the purchase of firewood when she adopts the use of the Elsa Stove. Felicia cannot wait to use the stove to reduce indoor air pollution and to save the lives of her children. Felicia is grateful to her micro lenders for their generous support.

loans.use: To buy a clean cook stove

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to buy more clothes to sell.

loans.name: Sumiati

texts.en:
This is the story of Rifki, son of Sumiati: 

I am the older child.  I have graduated from junior high school and plan on entering vocational school, SMK Yos Sudarso Majenang.  However, my family’s condition makes it hard for me to do so.  It’s difficult for me seeing my parents work to fund my study.  My father works as a labor whose income is uncertain while my mother works as a farm worker.  It’s already been hard for them to fund our daily needs and raise my little brother.  That’s why I hope I can get KIVA’s support, so I can continue my study and relieve my parent’s burden.

loans.use: to pay for education fees at the vocational school.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To purchase more clothes to sell

loans.name: Ada

texts.es: ADA ES UNA JOVEN DE 27 AÑOS, ESTUDIANTE DE LA CARRERA TÉCNICA DE ADMINISTRACIÓN Y NEGOCIOS INTERNACIONALES, TRABAJA EN UNA EMPRESA EN EL PUESTO DE CAJERA, ORGULLOSA DE ELLA MISMA  NOS CUENTA QUE SE  DECIDIÓ POR ESTA CARRERA PORQUE LE INTERESA MUCHO EL MUNDO DE LOS NEGOCIOS Y VER TODOS LOS ASPECTOS INTERNOS Y EXTERNOS DE UNA EMPRESA, NO ENCUENTRA OBSTÁCULO ALGUNO PORQUE LE GUSTA MUCHO LO QUE HACE Y SE HA PUESTO LA META  DE LLEGAR A CONSEGUIR UN PUESTO EN  EL ÁREA DE RECURSOS HUMANOS Y EN UN FUTURO LLEGAR A TENER SU EMPRESA. SOLICITO EL PRÉSTAMO PARA PAGAR GASTOS QUE TIENE EN SUS ESTUDIOS Y ADELANTAR  CUOTAS DE PAGO EN  EL INSTITUTO DONDE YA TIENE DOS AÑOS ESTUDIANDO, SE SIENTE MUY AGRADECIDA CON LOS INVERSIONISTAS DE KIVA YA QUE GRACIAS A LA AYUDA QUE LE BRINDAN PODRÁ CONSEGUIR LO QUE SE A PROPUESTO QUE ES TERMINAR BIEN EL AÑO ACADÉMICO Y FELIZ  DE SABER QUE EXISTEN PERSONAS  QUE LA VAN  A APOYAR.
texts.en:
Ada is a 27-year-old woman. She is pursuing a Technical degree in Business Administration and International Business Studies and works as a cashier for a company. 

She says proudly that she decided to pursue that degree because she is very interested in the business world and all the internal and external aspects of a company. There are no obstacles for her because she enjoys very much what she does, and she has set herself the goals of getting a job in human resources and having her own company in the future.

She is requesting a loan to cover the expenses related to her studies and to pay the institute tuition fees in advance. She has been studying at the institute for two years.

She is very grateful to Kiva lenders because thanks to their help, she will be able to achieve what she has set out to do, which is to finish the academic year successfully. She is happy to know that there are people who will support her.

loans.use: to pay her monthly institute tuition fees.

loans.name: Santa Lucia Group

texts.es:
21 mujeres integran este grupo llamado Santa Lucia, son todas amigas uy vecinas de la ciudad de Encarnación, están haciendo la encuesta de eliminación de la pobreza para ir mejorando la vida de cada una.
Una de las integrantes es la Sra. Maribel, quien se dedica a la venta de prendas variadas que ofrece de manera ambulante, es una mujer luchadora, que se sacrifica por su familia y sus seres queridos. Sueña con poder tener un local grande donde poder trabajar y hacer sus ventas.
Pide este préstamo para la compra de prendas variadas, de manera a poder seguir con su trabajo, luchando por mejorar sus condiciones de vida y las de su familia.
texts.en:
There are 21 women who make up the group named “Santa Lucia”. All of them are friends and neighbors from the city of Encarnación. They have taken the poverty elimination survey so that they can improve their lives.

One of the members is Sra. Maribel. She sells various types of clothes as a street vendor. Maribel is a determined woman who has made sacrifices on her behalf of her family and loved ones. She dreams of having a large shop where she can work and conduct her sales.

Maribel is requesting this loan in order to buy various types of clothes. This will enable her to continue her work. She strives to improve her living conditions and those of her family.

loans.use: to buy various types of clothes to sell.

loans.name: Veronika

texts.en:
Veronika is 18 years old and unmarried with 1 child. 

She owns and operates a small store, selling a variety of items. She has been doing this for 2 years. Veronika needs a loan to buy a chest freezer, snacks, frozen goods, canned food, sack of onions, toilet rolls and body care products. 

She hopes to use her profits to pay for the renovation of her house and help with her family's weekly expenses. She became a member of SPBD in 2012 to gain access to capital for her business.

loans.use: to buy a chest freezer, snacks, frozen goods, canned food, sack of onions, toilet rolls and body care products

loans.name: Ikram

texts.en: Ikram is a 46-year-old single woman from Lebanon. She works from her home where she produces homemade food. She makes delicious traditional groceries which she sells to many customers with barely enough revenue. And today, Ikram is eager to borrow a loan from Kiva partner Vitas s.a.l to purchase food provisions to carry on with increasing her production. Ikram is impatient to see the impact of the loan as she is sure that it will be positively executed.

loans.use: to purchase food provisions

loans.name: Rolando

texts.en:
Rolando is a 45-year-old resident of Intramuros, Manila City, Philippines. He is married to Gioleta and they have 6 children. Together with his children, he manages their household while operating the business. He works hard to meet his family's basic needs and to send his children to school.  

Rolando operates a food stall. He cooks meals and sells them. In the Philippines it is more economical to buy meals out instead of them cooking at home if the family is composed only of about 2 to 3 persons.  His regular customers are his neighbors and the local community.  He earns a minimum of PHP 500 in sales every day.

To help him operate his business, he is requesting a PHP 15,000 loan, which he will use to buy ingredients like meats, rice, vegetables, condiments and seasonings, and frozen food products. He is positive that the loan will boost his earnings from his food stall.  

Rolando dreams of giving his children a good education through all of his hard work. He also hopes to expand his business. He faithfully meets up with his co-fellowship members to share stories and also to draw strength and inspiration from the Word of God he studies.

* All CCT community partners/clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and pay micro-finance loans.

loans.use: To pay for fresh meat and other ingredients for his food stall to cook dishes for his customers.

loans.name: Marites

texts.en:
Marites is receiving a monthly allotment from her son abroad. With her aspiration to grow the money she is receiving from her son, Marites invested in a food vending business. 

Marites put up a carinderia (mini-restaurant) in the market for selling a different menu of meals. Due to an increasing number of customers, Marites’ business site is not able to accommodate all her customers. This reason encouraged her to borrow a loan of PHP 20,000 to buy materials for expanding her business site. She will also use some of her loan to buy raw meat and ingredients for cooking foods.

loans.use: to buy materials for expanding her business site.

loans.name: Bernardo

texts.en:
Bernardo is 68 years old and very responsible with his household obligations since he has always been known to provide the best for his family. He currently lives with his wife and seven children. He is a farmer who plants corn and bananas.

He wants to increase sales. Consequently, he has requested a loan that will enable him to purchase seeds, compost and fertilizer, among other items, so that he can continue to put bread on the table in his home.

loans.use: to purchase seeds, compost and fertilizer

loans.name: Noraita

texts.en:
As a married parent of six children, Noraita works hard to support her family.

She has a coconut farming business in the Philippines and also earns additional income from a general store, buying and selling dried coconut meat, motorcycle transport, and pig fattening. Noraita is borrowing PHP 50,000 through NWTF to purchase additional sacks of feed for her coconut.

She successfully paid back her previous loan, and now she has requested an additional loan to further build her business.

Noraita has been sustaining her business activities through her past loans from NWTF. She hopes that her hard work will help her attain her dream: to save money to expand her business.

loans.use: to purchase additional sacks of feed for her coconut

loans.name: Aida

texts.es: A sus 61 años de edad Aida  es madre soltera pero todos sus hijos ya son mayores de edad, ella para poder tener dinero que cubran sus gastos se dedica a la venta de LEUDINE  que son productos de salud,  belleza, cuidado de la piel y del cabello, entre otros, y también se dedica a la venta de ropa ofreciendo de puerta en puerta, Aida vive con una hija y 2 nietas en una casa por la que paga arriendo, el crédito lo necesita para comprar mercadería en LEUDINE, Aida tiene la aspiración de seguir adelante con su negocio que aunque para ella es un poco difícil ya que no camina normalmente porque tiene una enfermedad en su pierna esto  no le impide trabajar para cubrir sus  gastos diarios y no tener que pedirle a sus hijos ya que ellos tienen sus propias responsabilidades.
texts.en: At her 61 years of age, Aida is a single mother, but all of her children are already adults.  In order to have money to pay her expenses, she is engaged in selling Leudine, a brand of health, beauty, skin and hair care products.  She is also engaged in selling clothing door-to-door.  Aida lives with her daughter and two grandchildren in a rented house. She needs the loan to purchase Leudine merchandise.  She hopes to keep moving forward with her business although it is a little difficult for her as she cannot walk normally because of a condition in her leg.  This doesn’t stop her from working to pay her expenses and she doesn’t have to ask her children for money as they have their own responsibilities.

loans.use: to purchase Leudine products.

loans.name: Chansomaly

texts.en: A rural citizen from the Chol Kiri district in Kampong Chnang province, Chansomaly is married and has one son, who is still in school. Her main businesses are fishing and farming rice. She has been with VisionFund for 15 years. This is a first loan cycle for her. Now she is requesting a loan to purchase a solar panel for generating a lamp and pumping machine. She hopes to improve her standard of living.

loans.use: To purchase a solar panel for generating a lamp and pumping machine.

location.town: Kampong Chnang Province, Chol Kiri District

loans.name: Kanika

texts.en:
Kanika, at 23 years old, is married and the mother of two sons. She lives with her husband and sons in a small village, West Shalbari, in Dhupguri, Jalpaiguri district. Her sons are too young for school. 

Kanika's husband Ashok is a very entrepreneurial and hardworking youth. He was raised in the countryside and has done agricultural work most of his life. Currently he is engaged in agricultural activities on his own farmland, where he grows different seasonal vegetables, but he wants to start paddy rice cultivation, which would allow him to increase his income. Then he can help his family with the household expenses and also pay for his sons' studies. He is serious, responsible, and committed to his family and his work. So, he always wants to continue progress, searching for a better future.

For this reason, Kanika is requesting a business loan from BJS (Kiva's partner) to invest in the purchase of agricultural inputs such as paddy seeds and manure, with the goal of helping her husband to start his commercial project and be able to produce a harvest in excellent condition. All this will help them go forward, improving little by little his standard of living and that of his family.

Her dream is to construct a concrete house for them with the profit from her business. 

Kanika and her husband are grateful to BJS and Kiva.

loans.use: to purchase agricultural inputs for cultivating paddy rice.

loans.name: Judita

texts.en: Judita has been involving in business activities since 2012, and she started with her own working capital of $400. So now she is requesting a loan of $800 from Tuba Rai Metin, and she will use it to buy additional supplies to keep in her kiosk such as slippers, candies, detergent, salt, noodles, shampoo, soaps, aqua, and cooking oils to sell.  She is happy with the loan offered by Tuba Rai Metin because it will improve her business in the future, and also she will increase her income in the future.

loans.use: to buy slippers, candies, detergent, salt, noodles, shampoo, soaps, aqua, and cooking oils to sell.

loans.name: Laili

texts.en:
Twenty-year-old Laili is from Dhupguri. She is married and the mother of one daughter. Her husband Saidul is a farmer. She lives with her husband and daughter in Shalbari in Jalpaiguri district.

Laili’s husband has been growing paddy on his ancestral land. He works tirelessly from dawn to dusk to grow a good harvest and earn a livelihood for his family. He grows good-quality paddy and sells at a rate that is much cheaper compared to other farmers. But, his meager income can't cover all the necessary expenses of the family. So, Laili wants to help her husband by taking a loan from Kiva's partner, BJS.

The loan money will be used to buy seeds and other necessary ingredients for farming.  

Laili's big dream is to use the profit from the harvest to pay for her daughter's education and purchase a cycle van to give on rent for another means of income. She knows she will succeed with the help of this loan.

She is thankful to BJS and Kiva.

loans.use: to purchase farm supplies for cultivating paddy.

loans.name: Maa Tarini Group

texts.en:
Barsha, aged about 26 years, is the group leader of Maa Tarini , Bajantripara of Bolangir Town in the district of Bolangir, Odisha, India. She has a small family comprising four members: her husband, one son and one daughter, aged 5 and 7 respectively. The member standing third from the left with a raised hand in the second row is Barsha. 

At present, she is making handmade fans from bamboo with her husband. They are procuring raw bamboo from the forest or purchase it from the vendors, process it into fans and sell them in the market, railway station, or bus stand to earn their livelihood. Barsha’s husband is assisting her to sell the fans in the market. Their family income is Rs. 5,000 per month from their business. Barsha is a very active lady who wants some extra income out of her own efforts.

To improve her living condition and to earn some extra income, she wants to avail a loan from Mahashakti. With the loan amount, she will purchase huge quantities of raw bamboo from the vendors in bulk. She has a dream to increase her business and educate her children in a better school.

The other twelve members of her group are Archana, Gurei, Ritu, Soudmini, Babby, Santoshini, Rubi, Nandi, Padmini, Droupadi, Anjana, and Radhika, who are doing individual businesses.

loans.use: to purchase raw bamboo for making fans.

loans.name: Pratap Sagaren Group

texts.en:
Padmini is the leader of a group and lives in Hatipada of Bolangir Town in the district of Bolangir, Odisha, India. She is a married woman of 28 years. She has a small family comprising three members: her husband and one son, aged 7. The member standing fifth from the left with a raised hand in the second row is Padmini. 
Like most families in the locality, she and her husband are running a furniture shop in her house. She is a very active lady who wants some extra income out of her own efforts.

Her husband is assisting her to run the business smoothly in purchasing furniture items from the market. At present, her family income is Rs. 7,000 per month from the furniture shop, which is not sufficient to maintain her family. 

To improve her living condition and to earn some extra income, she wants to avail herself of a loan from Mahashakti. With the loan amount, she will purchase furniture items from Raipur in bulk quantity to avail herself of a cash discount and also save transportation cost, which she incurs frequently. 

She has a dream to have a wholesale shop in the town and to educate her children in a better college in the town.

The other 17 members of her group are Nandi, Sasmita, Lakshmi, Brunda, Madhuri, Sangita, Urmila, Banita, Rita, Lakshmi, Sapna, Ramil, Narmada, Kanti, Hada, Bhanumati, and Gulapi, who are doing separate businesses.

loans.use: to extend her furniture shop.

loans.name: Maa Mangala Group

texts.en:
Rajalaxmi, aged about 32 years, is the group leader of a group from Gatesorbar Para of Bolangir Town, in the district of Bolangir, Odisha, India. Her family comprises five members, her husband and two daughters, aged 14 and 10, and one son, aged 17. The member standing fifth from the right with a raised hand in the first row is Rajalaxmi. At present, she has been sewing dresses for ladies for the last five years and became a ladies’ tailor master in her locality. She is a very active lady who wants some extra income out of her own efforts.

Rajalaxmi’s husband is assisting her to run the business smoothly by taking thread, blouse pieces, buttons, etc. from the nearby town. At present, her family's income is Rs. 5,000 per month, which is not sufficient to maintain the family. 

To improve her living condition and to earn some extra income, she wants to avail herself of a loan from Mahashakti. With the loan amount, she will purchase a sewing machine and stitching materials in bulk quantities. 

She has a dream to have her own house, increase her business, stitch ready-made dresses and supply them to the market, and educate her children in better schools and college.

The other 15 members of her group are Sandhya, Rupakanti, Chandrakala, Padma, Laxmipriya, Tapa, Kentala, Kuntala, Bendala, Malati, Arnapurna, Rai, Pinki, Nirmala, and Tanaya, who are doing individual businesses.

loans.use: to purchase stitching materials.

loans.name: Claude

texts.en: Claude has started selling the clean energy products on his locality and has seen increased demand for these products. He has two children who have just started the school year so he is looking for a loan to help him purchase inventory for more goods.

loans.use: to purchase inventory for a clean energy retail business.

loans.name: Grace To Grace Group

texts.en:
Edward, 46, is happily married with three children aged seven, fifteen and eighteen years, all of whom are in school. He lives with his family in Abura Koforidua in central Ghana. For the past twelve years he has farmed both oranges and oil palms. His farm is the family’s only source of income.

Edward is a member and the leader of Grace to Grace Group. All of the members are citrus farmers and belong to a registered farming association. This association gives the members under contract an organized market for their crops. These association members have been receiving capacity building support from GIZ Germany Ghana Office and Ministry of Food and Agriculture (MOFA Ghana).

Edward is very positive about his farm’s future and wishes to maximize his yield to improve his income. However, he still must meet the high costs of maintaining his farm, in particular, laborers to weed and harvest his crops. As a whole the group needs general financial assistance to pay for farm maintenance, harvesting and transporting the crops to a point of sale.

With Edward as its leader, Grace to Grace Group is applying for a 4,800 GHS loan through ASA Initiative FNGO. From this loan Edward would receive 1,000 GHC to meet the financial needs of his farm and help him maximize his income. Among other things, profits from the farm will help pay the school fees for his children. Edward wishes to thank all microlenders for their generous assistance.

loans.use: to pay for laborers to weed and harvest his crops.

loans.name: Khuy

texts.en:
Khuy, who is 45 years old and a married man, lives in a community of Prey Veng province, Cambodia. He has two married children, and he also has six dependent children. He is an active and honest farmer who can make the income around USD 7 per day. So far, he has been a farmer for 21 years.  

Khuy wants to improve the general living conditions of the entire family by having a latrine to use, because there is no latrine in his house now. 

Therefore, he is borrowing a loan from Kiva to build a latrine. By doing this, he can help his family members gain access to sanitation, promote their health, and help to lessen environmental deterioration. 

He is thankful for the loan granted through HKL with a much lower interest rate than other general loan products.

loans.use: to build a latrine

loans.name: Lelibeth

texts.en:
Lelibeth works hard to support her family. She is 36 years old and has a business buying and selling used shoes in the Philippines. She has been in this business for seven years now.

She requested a PHP 9,000 loan through NWTF to purchase more stock of used shoes to sell.

She would like to save enough to provide a secure future for her family.

loans.use: to purchase more stocks of used shoes to sell

loans.name: Rowena

texts.en:
As the married parent of eight children, Rowena works hard to support her family.

She has a business buying and selling used shoes in the Philippines, and also earns additional income from buying and selling abaca (fiber used for business). Rowena is borrowing PHP 6,000 through NWTF to purchase more stock of used shoes to sell for her business buying and selling used shoes.

Rowena has been sustaining her business activities through her past three loans from NWTF. She hopes that her hard work will help her attain her dream of saving money to expand her business.

loans.use: to purchase more stock of used shoes to sell.

loans.name: Roda

texts.en:
Roda is 58 years old and married with three children. She works hard to provide for her family. She runs a general store in the Philippines. She has been running the general store for two years and also earns an income from buying and selling fruits and vegetables.

Roda has requested a 30,000 PHP loan through NWTF to purchase more items to sell like canned goods, eggs, milk, and sugar. She has borrowed and repaid 17 loans from NWTF before this loan. She aspires to build and expand her business to secure the future of her family.

loans.use: to purchase more items to sell like canned goods, eggs, milk, and sugar

loans.name: Hamaira

texts.en: Hamaira is a 47-year-old vigorous lady. She has been providing the service of tailoring for many years and is quite skilled at her job. She stitches for the people of her community and uses the income to support her entire family. She has five children. She is motivated to provide for her family. In her eighth loan cycle, she has requested a loan of 45,000 PKR. With this loan, she intends to purchase a new stitching machine and more stitching material such as needles, spools of thread, etc. She wants to generate more income in the future.

loans.use: to purchase a new stitching machine and more stitching materials such as needles, spools of threads etc.

loans.name: Jose Maria

texts.es:
José, es soltero, vive con su madre y una hermana, gran parte de los gastos familiares son costeados por don José; su actividad económica es cultivar granos básicos para consumo familiar y distribuirlo entre sus clientes ya establecidos, es un oficio que aprendió de muy joven, lo realiza con ayuda de mozos, pues su madre y su hermana se encargan de las labores domésticas.
Con el crédito comprara insumos agrícolas y pagara mozos para cultivar la milpa de postrera, con estos materiales dará un mejor trato a sus cultivos, mejora la producción y calidad de granos, con esta inversión busca tener mayores ventas y ganancias para cumplir con sus obligaciones.
Sus sueños son mantenerse trabajando para seguir apoyando a su madre y cambiar el estilo de vida familiar.
texts.en:
José is single and lives with his mother and sister.  José pays for a large portion of the family's expenses. 

His work is cultivating basic grains for both his family to eat and to distribute among the regular customers he has.  This is work he learned at a young age, and he performs it with the help of workers, since his mother and sister perform the domestic work of the house.

With the loan he will buy farming supplies and will pay workers to cultivate the cornfield behind him.  With these materials he will give better care to his crops, and increase the production and quality of his grain.  With this investment he looks to have greater sales and income in order to fulfill his obligations.

His dreams are to continue working to support his mother and to change his family's lifestyle.

loans.use: to purchase farming supplies and to pay workers to cultivate the cornfield behind him; with these supplies he will give better care to his crops.

loans.name: Isaias

texts.es:
Uno de los negocios característicos de Suchitepéquez es la crianza de animales de todo tipo. Desde hace tres años, Isaias de 36 años, quien vive en Suchitepéquez, se dedica a la crianza de pollos, negocio que genera una satisfactoria ganancia para poder superar en la vida.

La actividad que el realiza con tanto esfuerzo todos los días es la crianza de pollos en la comunidad donde el vive, el viene realizando dicha actividad durante más de 3 años dicho negocio le deja muy buena ganancia para mejorar las condiciones de vida de su familia y la de el.

Hace una solicitud de préstamo para la compra de más animales y los insumos como el concentrado que necesita para la crianza para luego venderlas por los alrededores de la comunidad y pueblos vecinas.

Son sus metas para generar más ingresos y el sostenimiento de su familia como el desarrollo de su comunidad donde el vive para que todos tengan las condiciones de vida adecuadas.
texts.en:
One of the characteristics of Suchitepéquez is the raising of animals of all types. Isaias is 36 years old and lives in Suchitepéquez. For two years, he has worked raising chickens. This business generates satisfactory profits to be able to get ahead in life. 

The activity he does with so much hard work, raising chickens, he does in the community where he lives. He has had this business for more than 3 years and it brings in good profits for him to improve his and his family's quality of life. He is applying for a loan to buy more animals and materials, such as the concentrate he needs to raise them and sell them around the community and in neighboring towns. 

His goals are to generate more income and support his family and the development of his community so that everyone can have adequate living conditions.

loans.use: Para la compra de pollos

loans.name: Nyame Die Group

texts.en:
Emma is a 52-year-old woman who is happily married, with six children. Her youngest child is 15 and is still attending school. Emma lives with her family in Abura Koforidua, in the central region of Ghana. 

Emma is a member of the Nyame Die Group. All the group members reside within the same community. Emma has been farming for the past 25 years, with a lot of experience. She grows palms and oranges for a living. She also owns a small provisions shop at her home to supplement her income. Emma and her group members are active members of their farming association. The association is responsible for marketing their crops to local industrial buyers. Emma's main challenge is the maintenance of her farm, as it is physically demanding. She is faced with the challenge of financing the cost of hired labour in weeding the farm. Additionally, Emma has to pay for the cost of harvesting the crops as well as transporting them to a sale centre for sale. 

A micro-loan of GHC1,000 will allow Emma to maximize her profit. Emma plans to invest her profit into her provisions store, as well as to further her child's education. Emma and her group members thanks all their micro-lenders for their generous support.

loans.use: To weed the farm and harvest the crops

loans.name: God's  Will Group

texts.en:
Isaac, aged 74, is a member of God's Will Group. He is happily married with six children, the youngest of whom is still attending school. He lives with his family in Abura Koforidua in central Ghana.

Isaac has been a farmer for the past twenty years and so has gained much experience. He grows oranges and cocoa on two separate farms. He belongs to a farming association that facilitates price negotiations and the marketing of its crops. While he is an enterprising and hardworking man, he finds his age is making it hard to maintain the farms by himself.

Isaac needs hired laborers to weed his farms and harvest the fruit, but there is the problem of how to finance that. As part of a group loan of 4,500 GHS through ASA Initiative FNGO Isaac would receive 1,000 GHC to pay for laborers on his farms. He will use his profits from the farms to pay for his last child's school fees and support his family.

Isaac would like to thank all microlenders for their generous assistance.

loans.use: To pay for laborers to weed his farms and harvest the crops

loans.name: Edith

texts.en:
Edith is a businesswoman from Chikomba East District of Zimbabwe. She is a Camfed Learner Guide volunteer who mentors secondary school students. Further, Edith started her poultry project in 2012; she produces 150 broiler birds every six weeks. Then she sells them to local residents.

Edith started her business because she saw the high demand for meat in her community. She will use the Kiva loan to purchase broiler chicks and chick feed in bulk. Edith hopes to provide for her family and remain financially independent.

loans.use: To purchase more chicks and feed

loans.name: Ellen

texts.en:
Ellen is a 26-year-old businesswoman who is married and has two children. Ellen lives in the Chikomba East District of Zimbabwe. She is a Camfed Learner Guide volunteer who mentors secondary school students. Ellen runs a grocery shop at her local shopping center, as well. 

Ellen will use the Kiva loan to purchase sugar, rice, Vaseline, soap, flour, cooking oil, and matemba (dried fish) in bulk to increase her sales and profits. She intends to improve her family’s quality of life.

loans.use: To purchase sugar, rice, Vaseline, soap, flour, cooking oil, and matemba.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To increase her inventory

loans.name: Ebenezer Nyame Group

texts.en:
Mary is a member of the Ebenezer Nyame Group. She is 48 this year, and is happily married with 5 children. All of her children are currently attending school. Mary lives with her family in Abrakrampa, in the central region of Ghana. Mary has been a farmer for 19 years. She grows oranges. She is also a trader and sells provisions as a side business, but her main source of livelihood is the income from the orange farm. Mary is also an active member of a registered local Citrus Farmers Association. 

Mary finds it difficult to maintain her farms because she cannot afford the financial demands of hiring workers to maintain the farm. She needs financial support in the form of micro loans to hire laborers to harvest and transport the crops to a point of sale. Mary's family is relying on the profit she takes home, particularly her children, who need this income to pay school fees. 

A micro loan of GHC1,500 will support Mary to achieve her business goal. Mary thanks all micro lenders for their generous support.

loans.use: To pay for labor to harvest the crops

loans.name: Right Time Group

texts.en:
Salamatu is the leader of the Right Time Group. All the group members are citrus farmers, and they belong to a registered farming association that liaises with development organizations to support their members. Salamatu is 40 years old. She is happily married, with 4 children, the eldest of whom is 22 and the youngest is 18. All of her children are attending school. Salamatu lives with her family in Abura Koforidua, in the central region of Ghana. 

Salamatu has been a farmer for the past 20 years. She has oranges, plantains, and oil palm plantations. Salamatu also owns a small provisions shop. Farming has been her major source of income in support of her family. Her only challenge now is the working capital needed to maintain the farms to maximize output. She is faced with the need to get financial assistance to pay for hired labourers to weed her citrus plantations. She also has to hire labourers to harvest and transport the crops from the farm to point of purchase. 

A micro loan of GHC1,500 will turn her story into a good harvest and a higher profit margin. She will make more than enough profit to repay her loan, and even have a surplus that will help her support her four children through school. 

Salamatu thanks all her micro lenders for their kindness.

loans.use: To weed and harvest the crops

loans.name: Simon

texts.es:
Simón tiene 59 años de edad, es conviviente, vive con su esposa e hijo de 15 años, en casa propia, en una comunidad grande en la zona urbana de Cayalti y goza con buenas referencias personales y laborales de parte de sus vecinos. Cayaltí, pertenece a la provincia de Chiclayo, región de Lambayeque, costa norte de Perú.

Simón se dedica a brindar el servicio de transporte público en mototaxi, con más de 8 años de antiguedad en el negocio, él brinda servicio en Cayalti y anexos. Simón solicita el préstamo para el mantenimiento y reparación de su mototaxi, asegurando de esta manera el correcto funcionamiento de su herramienta de trabajo, para poder seguir generando ingresos y poder en un corto plazo mejorar sus ganacias y su calidad de vida y la de su familia.
texts.en:
Simon is 59 years old. He owns the house where he lives with his common-law wife and their 15-year-old child.

His home is in a large community in the urban area of Cayaltí, which is located in the Chiclayo province in the Lambayeque region on the northern coast of Peru. Simon's neighbors have nothing but good things to say about his character and work.

Simon makes a living providing public transportation services on his motorcycle rickshaw. With over eight years of experience in the business, he provides services in Cayaltí and surrounding areas. 

Simon is requesting a loan to perform routine maintenance and repair work on his motorcycle rickshaw. In this way, he will ensure that the tool of his trade is in good working order, which will enable him to continue generating income and, in a short period of time, improve his profits, his quality of life and that of his family.

loans.use: to perform routine maintenance and repair work on his motorcycle rickshaw.

loans.name: Beatrice

texts.en:
Beatrice, 45, is married with four children aged between eight and eighteen years; three of them go to school.

For the past ten years Beatrice has sold charcoal. She is applying for a 500,000 RWF loan through Urwego to buy more charcoal to sell. The profits from the business will be used to pay her children’s school fees and reinvest in her business.

loans.use: to buy more charcoal to sell.

loans.name: Marie Cris

texts.en:
Marie Cris is married and lives with her husband in Misamis Occidental in the Philippines. Farming is the family’s main source of income, but she wants to improve her farm so she can make more in profits.

For a long time Marie Cris has been saving to buy a new motorcycle to be used to start up a transportation business, but most of her savings are spent on household expenses. Therefore, to improve their farm which is their main source of income, she has requested a 50,000 PHP loan through GDMPC so that she can use to purchase fertilizer and organic pesticides.

Marie Cris hopes to improve her farm so she can save more for her dreamed transportation services business as well as to improve the family’s general living situation.

loans.use: to purchase fertilizer and organic pesticides

loans.name: Xxxxx

texts.en: XXXXX is 30 years old and married. He operates a shop, which he has been doing for eight years. He requested a loan, which he will use to buy more sugar, salt, biscuits, and rice to sell. The profits from his business will be used to reinvest and to improve his standards of living.

loans.use: to purchase sugar, salt, biscuits, and rice to sell

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To purchase broiler chicks and chick feed in bulk to increase production.

loans.name: Izalobuhle

texts.en:
Izalobuhle is a 19-year-old businesswoman from the Umguza District of Zimbabwe. She lives with her parents and siblings.

Izalobuhle sells clothes, shoes and bags to people in her community. She also volunteers as a Camfed Learner Guide who mentors secondary school students.

Izalobuhle is applying for a 500 USD loan in order to buy clothing in bulk to sell. She will expand her business and pay for her siblings’ school fees.

loans.use: to buy clothing in bulk to sell.

loans.name: Angel

texts.en:
Angel is 18 years old and lives in Umguza District, Zimbabwe with her parents. She has been selling second-hand clothing in her community for three months. Angel is a Camfed Learner Guide who teaches life skills to secondary school students. 

Angel requested a loan, which she will use to purchase large volumes of clothing so that she could meet her customers’ demand.  Higher profits will allow Angel to further her education by enrolling in a teacher’s college.

loans.use: to purchase more clothes to sell

loans.name: Malati

texts.en:
Malati is a woman eager to get ahead. She is 41 years old, married, and lives with her husband Pulin in Dhupguri in the district of Jalpaiguri. Her husband, 49 years old, is a trader of betel nuts.

She has been practicing livestock breeding. She started this business with a small number of goats. Over time, her business increased more and more. Due to the miserable conditions of her family and the financial crisis that the family crossed into, she sold most of the goats in order to earn money to cover some of her household expenses.

Now, Malati wants to increase her business. Unfortunately, she does not have enough money to do that. For this reason, Malati applied for a loan from BJS in order to purchase goats to raise and sell to earn money, which will help her in improving the living conditions of her family. She also decided to sell goat milk to her neighbors to generate more income. 

Malati dreams to enlarge her business in order to earn more money to make a better future for her family and upgrade their house to a better and concrete one.

She thanks her generous lenders BJS and Kiva.

loans.use: to purchase goats for her animal husbandry.

loans.name: Nyame Akwan Group

texts.en:
Samata is a member of Nyame Akwan. She turns 61 this year, and she is a widow with five children. Her youngest child is now attending the university. Samata lives with her children in Abura Koforidua, which is in the central region of Ghana. 

Samata has been farming for 30 years. She grows oranges and palm on 8.5 acres of land. She also owns a small provisions shop, though farming remains her main source of income. Samata's farming association has obtained a contractual agreement with a local company that buys their crops from them for processing. Samata is thus very optimistic about her business prospects, and wishes to maximize her profit. Samata's only challenge now is how to get the financial support in maintaining the farms. She has to pay the wages for labour to weed, harvest and transport the crops to a sale centre for sale. 

A loan of GHC 500 will help her significantly, and her profits would far exceed the capital she needs to invest in her farm now. The income from her farm will also help pay the school fees for her youngest child at the university. 

Samata and her family thank all her micro-lenders for their generous assistance.

loans.use: To weed the farm and harvest the crops

loans.name: Tariro

texts.en:
Tariro is a 30-year-old businesswoman and mother from Buhera District, Zimbabwe. Over the last two years, she has grown her poultry business to its current capacity – producing about 50 broiler birds every six weeks and selling them to the local residents. Tariro started the business in 2012 because she wanted to be financially independent. She is also a Camfed Learner Guide who volunteers at the local secondary school. 

Tariro would like to increase her sales volume and become a supplier to major supermarkets. 

She will use the Kiva loan to purchase more broiler chicks and chick feed to increase production. She hopes to provide for herself and remain financially independent.

loans.use: To purchase more chicks and chick feed

loans.name: Victory Group

texts.en:
Amadu is a member of Victory Group. All the group members belong to a registered vibrant farming association. Amadu is 45 years old this year, and is happily married with two children, ages 18 and 8. Both of his children are in school. Amadu lives with his family in Abura Koforidua, in the central region of Ghana. 

Amadu has been farming for the past 12 years, and has gained much experience. He grows oranges on 10 acres of land. He is also a tailor, and though the tailoring business is doing well, his main source of income is still the farm. Amadu's farming association has obtained a contractual agreement with a local company that purchases the crops for processing into juice. He just needs to maximize his profit now, and his only challenge is the difficulty in getting the micro loans from financial institutions locally to finance the costs required to maintain the farm and harvest the crops. In particular, Amadu needs to hire laborers for weeding, harvesting the crops and transporting them to a sale centre for sale. 

A micro loan of GHC2,000 will help increase his profit significantly, and his profits would far exceed the capital he needs to invest in his farm now. Amadu will use the gain from the farm to care for his family, and also help pay the school fees for his children. 

Amadu and his family thank all their micro-lenders for their generous assistance.

loans.use: To weed the farm and harvest the crops

loans.name: Jerome

texts.en:
Jerome is 32 years old. He is married, with 3 children ages between 9 and 4 years; all of them go to school. He sells televisions and has been running in a business for the past 10 years. 

With the loan requested, he would like to buy more televisions to sell. The profits from the business will be used to reinvest and buy food for home consumption.

loans.use: To buy more televisions to sell.

loans.name: Perpetie

texts.en:
Perpetie is 39 years old. She is married with 5 children ages between 14 years and 6 months; 4 of them go to school. She sells shoes and has been running in a business for the past 10 years. 

With the loan, she would like to buy more shoes to sell. The profits from the business will be used to pay school fees for her children.

loans.use: To buy more shoes to sell.

loans.name: Beatrice

texts.en:
Beatrice is 36 years old. She is married with 6 children between the ages of 14 and 4 years; 4 of them go to school. She has a shop and has been working in a business for the past nine years. 

After getting loan, she would like to buy more sugar, salt, cooking oil and biscuits to sell. The profits from the business will be used to expand her business and pay school fees for her children.

loans.use: To buy more sugar, salt, cooking oil and biscuits.

loans.name: Mediatrice

texts.en: Mediatrice is 43 years old. She is married and has three children between the ages of 12 and 2 years. Two of her children go to school. She sells shoes and has been in sales for the past 10 years. With the loan, she would like to buy more sandals for resale. The profits from the business will be used to pay school fees for her children and to renovate her house.

loans.use: To buy more sandals for resale.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to connect to Haiti's first solar hybrid smart electricity grid.

loans.name: Gertrude

texts.en:
Gertrude is a 26-year-old entrepreneur from Buhera District, Zimbabwe. She is working as a Camfed Learner Guide volunteer at a local school; she mentors young students. In addition, Gertrude operates a flea market at the local business center. She sells products such as bags, shoes, jeans, shirts, skirts, tracksuits, and t-shirts. She has been running this business for one year now, and it has enabled her to support her family.  

With the Kiva loan, Gertrude will purchase bags, shoes, jeans, shirts, skirts, tracksuits, t-shirts, and phone airtime to increase her supplies. 

Her hope is to grow the business and open her own store. This will bring stability to her business, and will enable her to provide for her family’s basic needs. Gertrude also wants to improve her lifestyle and to build her own shop.

loans.use: To increase her stock

loans.name: Dorothy

texts.en:
Dorothy is a 36-year-old mother and businesswoman from Chikomba East, Zimbabwe. She is a Camfed Learner Guide volunteer who mentors secondary school students. Further, Dorothy rents a table at the local flea market. 

With the Kiva loan, Dorothy will purchase t-shirts, suits, shoes, and blankets to sell to her community. She intends to improve her standard of living and support her children.

loans.use: To purchase t-shirts, suits, shoes, and blankets.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To purchase more belts to sell

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To purchase more clothing stock

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To make bulk purchases of chicks, feed, and vaccines

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To increase her clothing stock

loans.name: Koro Ye Group

texts.en:
Nana came from Assin Fosu but currently lives in Assin Wawase with his family. They live in the Assin North District in the Central Region of Ghana. He is 45 years old and married with 5 children aged 19, 15, 12, 4 and 1 year. 

Nana has been growing a cocoa and palm plantation for the past 25 years. Nana's main challenge now is to secure a loan to purchase a clean cooking stove (aka an Elsa Stove) that utilizes waste products, such as palm kernel shells (virgin pellets) as fuel. Nana cannot wait to have this cost-saving and affordable clean cooking stove to improve his means of cooking. He is so eager because he can now find a use for his by-product virgin pellets, which will save him carrying firewood after a hard day's work. 

Nana and his group have decided to use clean cooking stoves to save the forest and as a way to reduce indoor/outdoor air pollution. Nana is now applying for 300 GHS to purchase an Elsa Clean Cook stove to protect his family from indoor air pollution and to reduce the cutting of trees from the forest in his village for charcoal and firewood. 

Nana and his entire group members say thank you to all their micro lenders for their kind support.

loans.use: to buy an Elsa Clean Cook stove.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to purchase groceries in bulk and add new products to her shop.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to connect to Haiti's first solar hybrid smart electricity grid.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to connect to Haiti's first solar hybrid smart electricity grid.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to connect to Haiti's first solar hybrid smart electricity grid.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to connect to Haiti's first solar hybrid smart electricity grid.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to connect to Haiti's first solar hybrid smart electricity grid.

loans.name: Venecia

texts.en: This loan helps Venecia get connected to her local prepay microgrid. Venecia is a 54-year-old, mother of four, all going to school. She is a reseller and lives in a small brown and pink wooden house in Les Anglais, in southern Haiti. She is seeking a loan from Kiva lenders to be able to connect to the local solar-powered microgrid, and to finally get rid of her dirty, costly kerosene lamp. Mainly, she is looking forward to being connected, as it will allow her to save money. Venecia and her family will now be able to benefit from a reliable, durable, and clean power source. After running pilots since 2012 that proved the benefits of prepay quality electricity to people in Les Anglais (first with 14 households, and up to 54), EarthSpark International is developing a full-scale, solar-powered microgrid. This micro-grid is expected to meet the needs of up to 500 households. Kiva loans allow EarthSpark to increase the number of beneficiaries by reducing the up-front costs for customers, and will be repaid over time by electricity sales. To see a video of Les Anglais and the hybrid solar grid, please click here.

loans.use: to connect to Haiti's first solar hybrid smart electricity grid.

loans.use: to connect to Haiti's first solar hybrid smart electricity grid.

loans.use: to connect to Haiti's first solar hybrid smart electricity grid.

loans.use: To increase her inventory

loans.use: To purchase more chicks, chick feed and medicines.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to connect to Haiti's first solar hybrid smart electricity grid.

loans.name: Violet

texts.en:
Violet is a 20-year-old businesswoman from the Chikomba East District of Zimbabwe. She is a Camfed Learner Guide volunteer who mentors secondary school students. Further, Violet started her poultry project in January; she produces 30 broiler birds every six weeks.

Violet will use the Kiva loan to purchase broiler chicks and chick feed in bulk to increase production. She hopes to provide for her family and remain financially independent.

loans.use: To purchase more chicks, chick feed and medicines.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To purchase more maize in large quantities

loans.name: Mary

texts.en:
Mary is a 28-year-old businesswoman from Buhera District, Zimbabwe. She is a volunteer Camfed Learner Guide who mentors secondary school students. Mary rents a table at the local flea market where she sells products such as bags, shoes, jeans, shirts, skirts, tracksuits, and t-shirts. She has been running this business for a year now and it has enabled her to support her family.  

With the Kiva loan, Mary will purchase bags, shoes, jeans, shirts, skirts, tracksuits, and t-shirts to increase her supplies. Her hope is to expand the business and open her own store. This will bring stability to her business and it will enable her to provide for her family’s basic needs, including education for her children.

loans.use: To increase her stock

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To purchase more grocery items to sell

loans.name: Adom Nsa Da Group

texts.en:
Esther is a 61-year-old single mother with 5 children. Her children are all still in school. Esther lives with her family in Abura Enyinabrim in the Central Region of Ghana. Esther is the group representative of Adom Nsa Da Group. All of the group members belong to a registered local farming association that facilitates marketing of their crops and farmers' capacity building.

Esther cultivates oil palm and orange plantations for a living. She has been growing oranges for the past 20 years and oil palm for 8 years. Esther is also a petty trader. However, her main source of income is from the farming activities.

Esther finds that attracting a micro-loan from the local financial institutions to maintain her farms is very difficult. She needs a loan of GHS 1,500 to hire labourers for weeding and harvesting. The income from her farm will help her support her children at home and through school. Esther also hopes to be able to build a small house for her family in five years if she can improve her income. She thanks all her micro-lenders for their support.

loans.use: to hire labourers to weed the farm and harvest the crops

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to increase her stock.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to purchase more broiler birds.

loans.name: Andrea

texts.es:
Andrea de 47 años de edad, su compañero de vida es agricultor y con él han procreado 6 hijos.

Andrea es empleada, tiene 20 años trabajando como promotora de salud en su comunidad, por lo que es conocida por su espíritu de servicio, también apoya a su pareja con las labores agrícolas.

El préstamo será utilizado para la compra de Semilla, fertilizantes y agroquímicos pala siembra de 7,000 mts. Cuadrados de Maíz que se usaran ya sea para consumo familiar o podría llegar a venderse.

Como todo buen padre Andrea espera con su pareja poder darles todo el estudio a sus hijos y que gocen de las comodidades que ellos no tuvieron.
texts.en:
Andrea, age 47, lives with her partner, who is a farmer. They have 6 children together.

Andrea is employed. She has been working as a healthcare promoter in her community for 20 years, for which she is known by her spirit of service. She also helps her husband with the farm work.

The loan will be used for the purchase of seed, fertilizer, and agrochemicals, in order to plant 7,000 square meters with corn, which will be used by the family, or perhaps sold.

Like all good parents, Andrea and her husband hope that they can provide an education for their children, and that they may enjoy the comforts that they have not had.

loans.use: to purchase seed, fertilizer, and agrochemicals, for planting corn.

loans.name: Macilia

texts.en: Macilia, 30, is a teacher and lives in a small white and pink house in Les Anglais, in southern Haiti. She is seeking a loan from Kiva lenders to be able to connect to the local solar-powered microgrid, and to get reliable electricity at home. Mainly, she is looking forward to being connected as it will allow her to save money. Macilia will now be able to benefit from a reliable, durable, and clean power source. This loan helps Macilia get connected to her local prepay microgrid. After running pilots since 2012 that proved the benefits of prepay quality electricity to people in Les Anglais (first with 14 households, and up to 54), EarthSpark International is developing a full-scale, solar-powered microgrid. This micro-grid is expected to meet the needs of up to 500 households. Kiva loans allow EarthSpark to increase the number of beneficiaries by reducing the up-front costs for customers, and will be repaid over time by electricity sales. To see a video of Les Anglais and the hybrid solar grid, please click here.

loans.use: to cover the upfront cost of connecting her home to Haiti’s first solar hybrid smart electricity grid.

loans.name: Peliana

texts.en: This loan helps Peliana get connected to her local prepay microgrid. Peliana is a 28-year-old mother of two, one of whom is going to school. She runs a small business and lives in a small pink and green wooden house in Les Anglais, in southern Haiti. She is seeking a loan from Kiva lenders to be able to connect to the local solar-powered microgrid, and to stop being intoxicated by candle fumes. Mainly, she worries that regular kerosene use is dangerous for her and her family. Peliana and her family will now be able to benefit from a reliable, durable, and clean power source. After running pilots since 2012 that proved the benefits of prepay quality electricity to people in Les Anglais (first with 14 households, and up to 54), EarthSpark International is developing a full-scale, solar-powered microgrid. This micro-grid is expected to meet the needs of up to 500 households. Kiva loans allow EarthSpark to increase the number of beneficiaries by reducing the up-front costs for customers, and will be repaid over time by electricity sales. To see a video of Les Anglais and the hybrid solar grid, please click here.

loans.use: to connect to Haiti's first solar hybrid smart electricity grid.

loans.name: Venecia

texts.en: This loan helps Venecia get connected to her local prepay micro-grid. Venecia runs a small business and lives with her husband and her four kids in the town of Les Anglais in southern Haiti. Their brown and pink wooden house has no reliable access to electricity and thus Venecia is forced to use costly and harmful kerosene for lighting. With all four of her kids still at school, she wishes they had better light for studying at night. A solar-powered micro-grid is being installed in Les Anglais, giving Venecia and her family the opportunity to connect to a higher quality, lower cost energy source - she is looking forward to being connected as it will allow her to save money. She is seeking a loan from Kiva lenders to cover the upfront cost of connection to the grid, which she will repay through her payments for electricity. An electrical connection dramatically reduces the cost of lighting in towns such as Les Anglais while offering far superior light quality and more generally providing opportunities for people to dramatically improve their quality of life. To see a video of Les Anglais and the hybrid solar grid, please click here.

loans.use: to connect to Haiti's first solar hybrid smart electricity grid.

loans.use: to purchase hair extensions, hair dryers, and hair lotions.

loans.name: Jonellee

texts.en: Due to financial hardship, Jonellee wants to access additional capital from Kiva lenders to improve her business. She is 47 years old and blessed with three children. She engages in buying and selling fruits and vegetables within the local community. She wants to obtain a loan of PHP 10,000 to buy more bananas, citrus, beans, cabbage, tomatoes and other leafy vegetables to resell. Being a hard working mother, she believes that she will be able to generate sufficient income and meet the necessities of her family.

loans.use: to buy more bananas, citrus, beans, cabbage, tomatoes and other leafy vegetables to resell

loans.name: Eriberta

texts.en:
This is Eriberta. She owns and operates an ornamental plant business to earn a living. She has been successful in this business for nine years, and she was able to repay her previous loan. She also finds ways to boost her income to provide for her everyday needs and expenses.

Eriberta would like to take out a new loan to buy additional gardening materials and supplies. She is requesting an amount of 11,000 Philippine pesos (PHP) to buy greater quantities and varieties of seeds and  fertilizers to plant and grow ornamental plants such as ylang-ylang, golden shower, dahlias and various hanging plants.

Eriberta still wants to grow her business and to create other sources of income. She also dreams of a well-to-do life and good health for her family. She meets up with her co-fellowship members to share stories of her work every week, and there she can also draw strength and inspiration from the Word of God she studies.

* All CCT community partners/clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and repay microfinance loans.

loans.use: to pay for gardening materials and supplies such as seeds and fertilizer needed for her business

loans.name: Kenneth

texts.en:
Kenneth is a 20-year-old merchant from Iloilo, Philippines. He runs a sari-sari or variety store business selling various goods and items to the people in his place. Kenneth lives in the typhoon-ravaged place in the country. 

Kenneth is asking for a loan to buy more stock to sell such as canned goods, noodles, biscuits, bread, soap and toiletries, cooking oil, and seasonings. With this, he will be able to improve his stock, thus allowing him to sell more to his customers. 

In the future, Kenneth hopes to make his business a success.

loans.use: to buy more stock to sell such as canned goods, noodles, biscuits, bread, soap and toiletries, cooking oil, and seasonings.

loans.name: Cecilia

texts.en:
Her name is Cecilia and she is a resident of Taguig City, Philippines. She is married to Wilfredo and has children. She manages her own household while operating the business. She works hard to provide income for their daily household needs and for the schooling of her children.

Cecilia maintains a direct selling business. She sells clothing, footwear, undergarments, cosmetics and other products through the popular direct selling brands like Avon, Natasha, and Boardwalk. Dealers buy the products at a price lower than the price shown on the catalogue for the customers and sell them at a profit.  Her regular customers are her neighbors, friends, family and the local community.  She earns a minimum of PHP 3,500 in sales every week.

To help her sustain her business, she is requesting a PHP 11,000 loan to buy merchandise items and orders of beauty products, toiletries and undergarments for her customers. Filipinos prefer to buy these branded personal goods because of their good quality. She is thanking God in advance for a good return on her investment and for the financial help that will be given to her.   

Cecilia fervently hopes that her child will be able to graduate one day. She faithfully meets up with her co-fellowship members to share stories of her work every week and draw strength and inspiration from the Word of God he studies.

* All CCT community partners/clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and pay microfinance loans.

loans.use: To purchase personal products like cosmetics, toiletries and undergarments.

loans.name: Sernalin

texts.en:
As a married mother of two children, Sernalin works hard to support her family.

She has a food vending business in the Philippines, and she earns additional income from raising livestock and selling salt. Sernalin is borrowing 20000 PHP through NWTF to buy ingredients for her food business.

Sernalin has been sustaining her business activities through her past ten loans from NWTF and more recently, through Kiva. She hopes that her hard work will help her attain her dream of saving enough money to expand her business.

loans.use: to buy ingredients for her food business.

loans.name: Agnes

texts.en:
Agnes is 36 years old and married with four children, three of whom are in school.  Agnes works very hard to provide for them.

Agnes runs a general store in the Philippines and requested a PHP 12,000 loan through NWTF to buy items to sell like shampoo, groceries, etc. 

Agnes has been in this business for four years. 

In the future Agnes would like to save enough money so she could afford to send her children to college.

loans.use: to buy items to sell like shampoo, groceries, etc.

loans.name: Mercedita

texts.en:
Mercedita works hard to support her family. She is married and has a fishing business in the Philippines.

She requested a PHP 15,000 loan through NWTF to buy additional fishing net, gasoline and other materials for fishing. She has been in this business for 16 years now.

In the future, Mercedita would like to save money to expand her business.

loans.use: to buy additional fishing net, gasoline and other materials for fishing

loans.name: La Bienveillance (1) Group

texts.en:
Isabelle is a member of the community bank group LA BIENVEILLANCE (1), and leads a subgroup of nine other micro-entrepreneurs in Brazzaville, the Republic of Congo. Four years ago, Isabelle started her own business selling plastic plates in the market to help support herself, her husband and her two grown children with their own families. Now well-established selling plastic plates, Isabelle wants to diversify her activities and open a new table in the market selling various groceries. In order to do so, Isabelle wants to take out a new loan of 400,000 CFA to purchase flour, rice and beans and be able to rent a second table.

Isabelle is currently on her fourth loan cycle with HOPE Congo since starting in 2013. She dreams of being able one day to open her own store and hopes that diversifying will lead her there. She also hopes that all of her children will do well and that in the future she will be able to build her own home.

loans.use: to purchase flour, rice and beans and be able to rent a second table.

loans.name: Estanislao

texts.es:
Estanislao de 51 años de edad, está casado y su esposa se dedica a los oficios domesticos y ambos han procreado un hijo, son conocidos en su comunidad por ser personas de bien.

Estanislao desde pequeño trabajo con su padre como agricultor, de él fue que aprendió el oficio y hasta hoy en día trabaja la tierra para tener ingresos económicos y mantener su familia.

El préstamo será utilizado para comprar ganado en regular estado, para luego engordarlo y venderlo a un mejor precio del que lo compró para así tener un ingreso extra para su familia.

Las proyecciones de Estanislao son obtener cosecha abundante de granos, para abastecer a su familia y poder vender una parte, también que salgan bien sus planes con la venta del ganado y con esos ingresos y un nuevo financiamiento mejorar su vivienda para comodidad y seguridad de su familia.
texts.en:
Estanislao, of 51 years old, is married and his wife dedicates to the household chores. They both have a son and are known in their community for being good people.

Since he was young, Estanislao worked with his father as a farmer, and that’s how he learned about the job.  Until this day he works the land to have incomes and support his family.

The loan will be used to buy cattle in regular conditions, fatten it up and then sell it for a better price so he can obtain an extra income for his family.

Estanislao’s projections are to obtain an abundant harvest of grains to supply his family and sell part of the outcome. He also hopes that the sale of his cattle will go well, and with that income and a new loan he’ll be able to improve his house for the commodity and safety of his family.

loans.use: to buy cattle, fatten it up and sell it.

loans.name: La Bienveillance (2) Group

texts.en:
At 40 years old and the proud father of four children, ages twelve to one, Philippe has long been in the business of learning how to raise and sell pigs. He is now the owner of a small business selling pigs in his own neighborhood, a recent development in the last three years. Last year Philippe joined HOPE Congo and became a member of the community bank group LA BIENVEILLANCE (2). There he leads a small group of ten other micro-entrepreneurs in Brazzaville, the Republic of Congo.

Philippe is currently on his fourth loan cycle with HOPE Congo and would like to take out a loan of 400,000 CFA to continue to grow his business. With this loan, Philippe will be able to reinforce his stock of pigs, which he then sells to individuals or restaurants. One day, Philippe wants to be able to have his own farm and raise his own pigs instead of having to purchase them from farmers far outside of the city and sell them downtown himself. With his earnings he hopes to ensure his children are well off and that they too might learn his trade.

loans.use: to purchase pigs for his farming activities

loans.name: Sriya Group

texts.en:
Padmini, the leader of the group, lives in Shivashankar Pada in Tarbha town in the district of Subarnapur, Odisha, India. She is a married woman of 39 years. She has a small family comprised of four members including her husband, one son and one daughter who are 8 and 10 years old, respectively. The member sitting first from the left with her hand raised in the first row is Padmini.
 
Like most families in the locality, she and her husband are running a Tiffin hotel in her house. Her husband helps her in procuring raw materials like sugar, rice, etc. for Tiffin purposes from town, and prepares and and sells the Tiffin. (Tiffin is a light meal)  This is the first loan she is taking. To improve her living conditions and earn some extra income, she wants to avail herself of a loan from Mahashakti Foundation. To take the loan, she formed a group of 12 women from her locality. At present, her monthly income is Rs 6,000 from her business, which is not sufficient to lead a better life. So, she wants to take a loan to purchase a lot of Tiffin materials in bulk to save transportation costs and time. She has a dream of having a good hotel in her locality and educating her children in a better school.

The other 11 members are Nagina, Akhtari, Madhubati, Muni, Rukasana, Hira, Sumitra, Saila, Bhumisuta, Yogeswari & Jhumi doing separate business

loans.use: to purchase grocery items

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to purchase more chicks and chick feed.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to purchase clothes.

loans.name: Maa Laxmi Group

texts.en:
Rupakanti is the leader of a group and lives in Pandarapita in the Tarbha block in the district of Subarnapur,Odisha, India. She is a married woman of 31 years. She has a small family comprised of four members: her husband, one daughter and one son. Her children are 8 and 10 years old. The member sitting in the middle of the first row with her hand raised is Rupakanti.
  
Like most families in the locality, she and her husband are running a Grocery Shop and sell rice, dal, sugar and other daily needs in her shop. She sells grocery items in her shop.  She is a very active lady who wants some extra income out of her own efforts.

Rupakanti’s husband helps her in purchasing grocery items from the nearby town to run the shop smoothly .At present, her family income is Rs 6,000 per month from her grocery shop, which is not sufficient to maintain her family.
 
To improve her living conditions and earn some extra income, she wants to avail herself of a loan from Mahashakti.  With the loan, she will purchase rice in bulk quantity to avail herself of a cash discount and save transportation costs, which she incurs frequently. She has a dream of having a wholesale shop in the town and educating her children in a better school in town.

The other 13 members of her group are Lija, Parbati, Belamati, Chandan, Puspanjali, Ahalya, Kalpana, Subidha, Patri, Sabitri, Padmini, Kure, and Janata doing individual businesses in the town.

loans.use: to purchase rice in bulk

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to purchase more stylish ready-made women's and children's clothes and other kinds of accessories to sell

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to purchase more bags, shoes, jeans, shirts, skirts, tracksuits, and t-shirts.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to purchase birds and feed.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to purchase flour, sugar, and cooking oil to increase her inventory.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to purchase groceries.

loans.name: Vasil

texts.ru:
Василь — предприниматель-сельскохозяйственник. У него дома 3 теплицы (одна — 2 сотки, другие — по 3 сотки), в которых он выращивает цветы и огурцы. Наемных рабочих в хозяйстве нет — со всем справляется семья: Василь, жена и 3 детей. Земельный участок находится прямо возле их жилого дома. 
Василь хочет на 20 000 гривен закупить семена, пленку, удобрения, а также сделать в одной из теплиц небольшой необходимый ремонт. Со временем Василь планирует построить еще одну теплицу, так как земельный участок это позволяет.
texts.en:
Vasil is a farmer and an entrepreneur. He has two greenhouses (one is 200 square meters and the other is 300 square meters), where he grows flowers and cucumbers. It is up to him to take care of the whole family: himself, his wife, and three children. He has a plot of land right next to the house. 
Vasil wants a loan of 20,000 hyrvnia to buy seeds, plastic sheeting and fertilizers, and to make the necessary repairs to one of his greenhouses. He also plans to build another greenhouse since he has the land to do so.

loans.use: to fix one of his greenhouses and to purchase plastic sheeting, seeds and fertilizers

loans.name: Pablo

texts.es:
El socio pertenece al banco comunal SAN RAFAEL, él banco está ubicado en el departamento de Cusco.
El socio tiene 50 años de edad tiene 01 hijo y es soltero, el socio alterna sus actividades diarias con el negocio de carpienteria, el socio lleva buen tiempo con su negocio el cual le  va bien gracias al empeño que le pone cada día a su negocio, el socio elabora muebles, mesas, camas entre otros el socio desea poder seguir trabajando para de eta forma seguir apoyando a su familia.
El socio solicita el crédito para la compra de madera.
El socio se siente agradecido por el crédito otorgado y se compromete a cumplir con sus cuotas establecidas.
texts.en:
Pablo belongs to the communal bank San Rafael, a bank located in the Cusco department.

He is 50 years old, has one son and is single. He alternates his daily activities with a carpentry business. 

He has a good time with the business, which is going well thanks to the effort he puts into his business every day. He makes furniture, tables, beads, among other. He wants to be able to continue working in order to support his family.

He seeks a loan to buy wood. He feels grateful for the issued loan and promises to comply with established quotas.

loans.use: to buy wood.

loans.name: Tha

texts.en:
Tha, age 41, is a vegetable farmer, while her husband is a traditional musician who assists his wife in farming when he is free. She is asking for a loan for capital to buy seed, fertilizer and pesticide.

Tha has been married since 1995 and she has three children-two are garment factory workers and another one is still young.  

Tha is pictured at home, not at the farm.

loans.use: to buy seed, fertilizer, and pesticide.

loans.name: Diosdidit

texts.en: Diosdidit is a fisherman from Iloilo, Philippines. He is a married man and a father of two young children. Diosdidit has been in the fishing business for more than 3 years now. This is the source of his income. Diosdidit’s fishing business was affected when a super typhoon hit the country several months ago. As of now, Diosdidit has just started to rebuild his business. He is requesting a loan to buy materials for the repair of the fishing boat like plywood, wood, nails and paint. With this, he will be able to go back to fishing in order to earn income. Diosdidit hopes to make his business a success. Moreover, he wants to save money for the future schooling of his children.

loans.use: to buy materials for the repair of his fishing boat like plywood, wood, nails and paint

loans.name: Biết

texts.en:
Biết works in agriculture farming food.

Biết is 40 years old and is married with two children.
Biết  lives in Quang Xuong district, a rural town in Thanh Hoa province.

In 2013, Biết  joined Thanh Hoa Fund for Poor Women to improve her  business. Biết  has successfully repaid one loan from Thanh Hoa Fund for Poor Women.

Biết  has been involved in this business for more than 10 years.
The main hardship that Biết faces in her life is not having a hygienic latrine. She is requesting a loan to purchase sand, cement and brick to build a toilet.

With her business profit, Biết  hopes for her family to be healthy and happy, for her business to do well, and for her children to find a good job.

loans.use: to purchase sand, cement and brick to build a toilet.

loans.name: Lay

texts.en:
Lay, 44 years old, is single mother of one dependent child and one married child. She lives in the village of Prey Chhor District, Kampong Cham Province, Cambodia. To make a living and support her family, she manages and operates a farming business on a small farmland that is located near her house. The profit that she can make is USD 5.00 a day. So far, she has been in this career for 15 years.

Currently, Lay wants to have a motorbike to as a personal use. Because there is not enough money, she would like to request a Kiva loan to buy a motorbike. She would like to thank all the lenders for the financial support via HKL, which provides her with a much lower interest rate than its general loan product.

loans.use: to buy a motorbike.

loans.name: Donald

texts.en:
Donald is from Lapasan, Clarin, a 32-year-old father of four children. He operates a transportation and rental service  business while he is working in a private institution to make a living. He successfully repaid his previous loan used for repair of his vehicle. His wife is selling cosmetic products in order to earn additional income for the family.

Recently, Donald took a new loan to repair his vehicle. A portion will be used for the medical maintenance costs for his wife who suffered illness from a bone fracture. He is thankful for  this loan that helped his business as well as the health conditions of his family.

loans.use: to repair his motorcycle and cover medical expenses for his wife's fracture

loans.name: Mirasol

texts.en:
Mirasol is grateful that she was previously granted a PHP 50,000 loan, which she used to buy alkaline filters needed in her water distribution business. She has been a distributor of water in her community for five years. Part of the loan was also used in her laundry shop. She and her husband work hard to provide for their daily basic needs and for the schooling of their children.

To maintain good service of her water distribution, she would like to apply for a PHP 30,000 loan, which she will use to buy filters. She is thanking God and you in advance for the financial support that will be given to her.

Mirasol hopes that her business will continue to exist and dreams of giving her family a good life. She meets up with her co-fellowship members to share stories of her work every week, where she can also draw strength and inspiration from the Word of God she studies.

* All CCT community partners/clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and pay micro finance loans.
